facts.text: FC Dallas was originally founded as the Dallas Burn in 1995.
FC Dallas adopted its current name in 2004.
FC Dallas won their first Supporters' Shield in 2016.
FC Dallas was the runner-up in the MLS Cup in 2010, losing to the Colorado Rapids in extra time.
FC Dallas has won the U.S. Open Cup on two occasions, in 1997 and 2016.
North Texas SC, the fully owned USL affiliate of FC Dallas, won the 2019 USL League One regular season and overall championship titles.
The International Federation of Football History & Statistics placed FC Dallas as the 190th best club in the world and the ninth best in CONCACAF at the end of 2016.
FC Dallas played their first game on April 14, 1996, defeating the San Jose Clash in a shootout win.
Jason Kreis scored the team's first goal on April 19, 1996, in a 3–0 home win over the Wiz.
In 1997, FC Dallas (then Dallas Burn) won their first U.S. Open Cup by defeating D.C. United.
In 1999, striker Jason Kreis was voted the league's MVP, becoming the first player to reach 15 goals and 15 assists in a season.
Mike Jeffries won the 1998 MLS Cup and two U.S. Open Cups with the Chicago Fire before replacing Dir as Dallas's coach in January 2001.
In 2001, Dallas was eliminated in the playoff quarterfinals by the Chicago Fire, Mike Jeffries' former team.
The 2001 U.S. Open Cup saw Dallas eliminated in the second round by the Seattle Sounders Select, an amateur team from the third-tier Premier Development League.
For the 2003 season, Dallas relocated their home games from the Cotton Bowl to Dragon Stadium in Southlake, a northern Fort Worth suburb.
In 2005, FC Dallas signed Guatemalan forward Carlos Ruiz, who had previously scored 50 goals in 72 games for the Galaxy and earned the MVP award for helping them to the 2002 MLS Cup.
FC Dallas played their inaugural game at Pizza Hut Park on August 6, 2005, tying with the New York/New Jersey MetroStars 2-2.
FC Dallas lost in the conference semifinals to the Colorado Rapids in a penalty kick shootout during the 2005 playoffs.
In 2006, FC Dallas finished the regular season at the top of the Western Conference but lost in the conference semifinals, leading to coach Steve Morrow's dismissal.
FC Dallas reached their first two U.S. Open Cup finals since their 1997 victory in 2005 and 2007, losing both times by one-goal margins to the Galaxy and the New England Revolution respectively.
Dallas played in the MLS Cup for the first time in 2010, losing 2-1 after extra time to Colorado at BMO Field in Toronto.
David Ferreira, on loan from Colombia, was voted the league's MVP in 2010, having missed only one minute of the season.
Schellas Hyndman won the MLS Coach of the Year Award in 2010.
Dallas competed in the CONCACAF Champions League for the first time during the 2011-12 season.
Dallas became the first MLS team to win an away match in the Champions League against a Mexican team by defeating UNAM in 2011.
Óscar Pareja was confirmed as the head coach of Dallas three months after Hyndman's resignation in October 2013.
Dallas won their first Supporters' Shield and second U.S. Open Cup in 2016.
Dallas was eliminated from the Champions League by Pachuca after a late goal in overtime from Hirving Lozano during their home and away semifinal series.
The Dallas Burn re-branded as FC Dallas in 2005 to coincide with their move to Pizza Hut Park.
FC Dallas's original colors were red and black, and the team played in these colors until their rebranding in 2005.
FC Dallas has had three different home stadiums, all located in the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex.
Toyota Stadium became the home of FC Dallas in August 2005 and is the third American soccer-specific stadium.
The National Soccer Hall of Fame is located in the south end of Toyota Stadium, which was remodeled in 2018.
The $182 million redevelopment of FC Dallas' stadium is scheduled to be completed before the 2028 season.
The mascot of FC Dallas is a bull named Tex Hooper, who was "born" on September 6, 1996, in Frisco, Texas.
FC Dallas' main rival is the Houston Dynamo, with whom they compete for El Capitan, a working replica Civil War cannon.
The Brimstone Cup is a rivalry cup contested between FC Dallas and the Chicago Fire, inaugurated by the fans in 2001.
The Lamar Hunt Pioneer Cup is a rivalry cup contested between FC Dallas and Columbus Crew SC since 2007, named after Lamar Hunt, an investor in both teams.
FC Dallas' team anthem, created during a period where MLS created songs for each club, was "H-O-O-P-S Yes!" and performed by The Polyphonic Spree.
In 2020, the FC Dallas Academy was ranked the number one academy in MLS by David Kerr on chasingacup.com MLS Academy rankings.
FC Dallas was formally associated with Oklahoma City Energy FC of the USL Championship and Arizona United SC of the USL in 2015.
North Texas SC, owned and operated by FC Dallas, was officially announced on December 6, 2018, and now plays in the MLS Next Pro league.
In 2005, Pizza Hut was the title sponsor of FC Dallas's stadium when it opened.
On June 27, 2012, FC Dallas reached a three-year sponsorship deal with AdvoCare worth US$7.5M, making AdvoCare the official jersey sponsor.
After the 2012 season, Pizza Hut ended their relationship with FC Dallas, leading to the stadium being temporarily renamed as FC Dallas Stadium.
In September 2013, FC Dallas reached a long-term deal with Toyota for stadium naming rights, renaming it Toyota Stadium.
In October 2014, FC Dallas and AdvoCare announced an extension of the jersey sponsorship through 2020.
In February 2021, FC Dallas announced MTX Group as its new shirt sponsor, with Advocare remaining as the team's sleeve sponsor.
In January 2023, FC Dallas announced a sponsorship deal with Children's Health and UT Southwestern as its new jersey sponsors.
Since the 2023 season, all live FC Dallas matches stream on MLS Season Pass as part of the league's exclusive broadcast rights agreement with Apple Inc.
Before the all-streaming deal in 2023, FC Dallas's non-nationally televised games were primarily broadcast in Dallas on local channel KTXA, starting with the 2015 season.
In August 2018, FC Dallas launched the FCDTV Network, comprising local stations in Amarillo, Lubbock, Tyler-Longview, and Wichita Falls/Lawton.

On February 25, 2013, FC Dallas signed a deal with Time Warner Cable to air most of its games on the Time Warner Cable Sports Channel in Dallas, replacing Fox Sports Southwest as the primary broadcaster for two seasons.
Until the 2012 season, FC Dallas matches appeared on various local television stations such as KTXA and WFAA, and regional sports network Fox Sports Southwest.
In 2012, Dallas Mavericks play-by-play announcer Mark Followill became the primary play-by-play announcer for FC Dallas, replacing the late Bobby Rhine.
Steve Davis has been the analyst on all FC Dallas matches since 2018.
In what year did FC Dallas announce Estrella TV as their first regional Spanish television partner? Answer: 2021
Under what branding did FC Dallas announce it would air Tuesday-night encores of matches on KDFI in 2025? Answer: FC Dallas Rewind
Since what season has English radio coverage of FC Dallas' MLS matches been available on the club's website? Answer: 2018 season
Who has been FC Dallas' Spanish language play-by-play announcer since the inaugural 1996 season? Answer: Carlos Alvarado
In what year did FC Dallas win their first Supporters' Shield? Answer: 2016
FC Dallas was the MLS Cup Runners-up in which year? Answer: 2010
How many times has FC Dallas won the U.S. Open Cup as of the last update? Answer: 2 times (1997, 2016)
In what years did FC Dallas win the Copa Tejas (Division 1)? Answer: 2021, 2024
FC Dallas reached the semi-finals of the CONCACAF Champions League in which season? Answer: 2016-17
FC Dallas won which international competition in 1998? Answer: CONCACAF Cup Winners' Cup
Club Atlético Nacional Medellín was ranked as the top club in the CLUB WORLD RANKING 2016 by IFFHS.
FC Dallas was originally known as Dallas Burn in 1996.
FC Dallas shut out Kansas City with a score of 3–0 on April 19, 1996.
Los Angeles defeated Dallas 3–1 to win the West and advance to the MLS Cup in 1999.
FC Dallas played at Dragon Stadium in Southlake for the 2003 MLS season.
Dallas Burn returned to the Cotton Bowl for the 2004 MLS season.
The Dallas Burn changed their nickname to FC Dallas in 2004.
Pizza Hut Park, the stadium for FC Dallas, opened in 2005.
The Los Angeles Galaxy won the U.S. Open Cup title on a goal by Herculez Gomez in 2005.
The New England Revolution won their first trophy, defeating FC Dallas 3–2 in the 2007 Final of the U.S. Open Cup.
Colorado Rapids defeated FC Dallas to win the 2010 MLS Cup.
FC Dallas reached the MLS Cup Final in 2010.
FC Dallas won the U.S. Open Cup Final in 2016.
The Brimstone Cup and Texas Derby are rivalry cups associated with FC Dallas.
Oscar Pareja served as the head coach of FC Dallas from 2014 to 2018.
The Columbus Crew won the MLS Cup in 2023.
The New York Red Bulls won the MLS Cup in 2024.
D.C. United won the MLS Cup in consecutive years from 1996 to 1999.
The LA Galaxy reached the MLS Cup Finals in 1996, 1999, 2002, 2005, 2009, 2011, 2012, and 2014, winning in several of those years.
Which team was the first to win the MLS Supporters' Shield in 1996?
In what year did Inter Miami CF win the MLS Supporters' Shield?
Which team won the U.S. Open Cup in 1999, breaking away from MLS teams' dominance in the competition?
Rochester Rhinos
Which team won the U.S. Open Cup three consecutive times from 1967 to 1969?
New York Greek American Atlas
In what year did the New York Red Bulls win their first MLS Supporters' Shield?
What team won the U.S. Open Cup in both 2019 and 2024?
Who won the U.S. Open Cup in 1987?
Club España
Which city's districts include the Asian Trade District, Deep Ellum, and Uptown?
Dallas
